ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, I just finished reading your paper.  Cool stuff.  It s exciting to see you expand NEAT in such a novel way.  I have a few comments and questions. 1) I

Hi Ken,

I just finished reading your paper.  Cool stuff.  It's exciting to=
 see
you expand NEAT in such a novel way.  I have a few comments and questi=
ons.

1) I agree there is intuitive appeal to the CPPN scheme.  The way
sub=
tle elaborations are applied to core structure seems powerful.  But
I can't=
 see what the next step from here is - specifically, to produce
an ANN.  
T=
he examples in the paper produce 2D greyscale images.  Do you already
have =
ideas how a CPPN would produce a directed network graph with
connection wei=
ghts?  I suppose one simple scheme would be to interpret
the X and Y inputs=
 as neuron IDs, and the output as the connection
weight between those IDs. =
 The range and density of neuron IDs would
need to be represented somehow. =
 Does that seem lik the right track? 
Do you envision CPPNs with multiple o=
utputs?

2) Can you give a short definition of "gradient" and "coordinate
f=
rames" in the context of the paper?  They're used several times, and
I thin=
k I have the general idea from context.  But they are pivotal to
this domai=
n, so I want to make sure I have a clear understanding.

3) You list repeti=
tion, repetition with variation, symmetry, imperfect
symmetry, elaborated r=
egularity, and preservation of regularity as the
6 patterns exhibited in na=
ture that a good model should include. 
Other than your own intuition, is t=
here any justification for this
being a necessary and complete list?

4) I'=
m skeptical of the human-guided evolution process you used with
evolutionar=
y art.  It seems like you're arguing that an important step
on the path to =
evolving a bird is to evolve a bird-shaped picture. 
But birds weren't sele=
cted because somebody thought they looked like
birds, they were selected mo=
stly based on behavior.  
You mention 2 other schemes (L-Systems and Turing=
's "reaction
diffusion model") that produced organic-looking structures.  T=
hose
were both around 50 years ago (I think), and they haven't (as far as I=

know) led to serious biologically-inspired computer systems.

5) You draw =
a strong dichotomy between CPPNs and develompental
processes because CPPNs =
aren't time-based.  But, the CPPN network is
going to have to be activated,=
 and each step is going to take time. 
Also, one could view the model as ha=
ving one of the inputs be time. 
It can be very fast, but a gene regulatory=
 network in a computer is
much faster than a biological one.  Am I missing =
something here?

6) This is a semantic nitpick.  You write in paragraph 4 o=
f section
2.3, "[biological evolution] does not start searching in a space =
of
the same complexity as the final solution".  Describing evolution as
hav=
ing a "final solution" is misleading - it makes it seem directed. 
There is=
 no final solution, there are just solutions good enough to
survive.

- Phi=
lip
